contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox former Arab villages in Palestine |name=Arab al-Samniyya |image= |imgsize= |caption= |arname=عرب السمنية |meaning= |altSp=Arab al-Samniya |district=ac |latd=33|latm=02|lats=48 |longd=35|longm=10|longs=50 |population=200 |popyear=1945 |area = 1,872<!-- this will be interpreted as dunams --> |areakm=1.872 |cause=M |curlocl=[[Ya'ara]] |pushpin_map=Mandatory Palestine |date=31 October 1948<!-- assumed to be date of capture, please confirm or correct --> }} '''Arab al-Samniyya''' ({{lang-ar|عرب السمنية}}), also known as Khirbat al-Suwwana, is a depopulated [[Palestinian people|Palestinian]] [[village]] in the [[Galilee#Western Galilee|Western Galilee]] that was captured by [[Israel]] during the [[1948 Arab-Israeli war]]. It was located in the [[District of Acre|Acre District]] of the [[British Mandate of Palestine]], 19.5 km northeast of the city of [[Acre, Israel|Acre]]. In 1945 the village had a population of 200 [[Arab]]s and a total land area of 1,872 [[dunam|dunums]]. ==Before 1948== The village was situated on a rocky hill near the road linking [[Ra´s al-Naqura]] with [[Safad]]. Its houses were made of stone. A dirt path linked it to the coastal highway and thence to [[Acre, Israel|Acre]]. The villagers cultivated grain, figs, and olives. In 1944/45 a total of 174 [[dunam]]s were allocated to grain crops; 22 dunums were irrigated and planted with orchards.<ref>Khalidi, 1992, p.5</ref> ==1948 War== The village was captured by Israel's [[7th Brigade (Israel)|7th]] and [[Carmeli Brigade|Carmeli]] Brigades on 31 October 1948 during the [[Israeli Defense Force]] offensive, [[Operation Hiram]]. The village was completely destroyed, and only building rubble left behind. The village remained depopulated of its inhabitants. In 1950, the [[Jewish settlement]] of [[Ya'ara]] was established on the depopulated land.<ref>Khalidi, 1992, p.6</ref> [[Image:Saasaa 1948.jpg|250px|left|thumb|IDF soldiers during Operation Hiram, photographed at [[Sa'sa']], 30 October 1948]] ==See also== *[[List of Arab towns and villages depopulated during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{Refbegin}} *{{Citation|title=Village Statistics of 1945: A Classification of Land and Area ownership in Palestine|url=http://www.palestineremembered.com/Articles/General-2/Story3150.html|first1=Sami|last1=Hadawi|authorlink=Sami Hadawi|year=1970|publisher=Palestine Liberation Organization Research Center}} *{{Citation|title=All That Remains|first1=Walid|last1=Khalidi|authorlink=Walid Khalidi|year=1992|location=[[Washington D.C.]]|publisher=[[Institute for Palestine Studies]]|ISBN=0-88728-224-5}} *{{Cite book|url=http://books.google.com/?id=uM_kFX6edX8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=benny+morris&q |first=Benny |last=Morris |authorlink=Benny Morris |year=2004 |title=The Birth of the Palestinian Refugee Problem Revisited|isbn=978-0-521-00967-6 |publisher=Cambridge University Press}} {{Refend}} ==External links== *[http://www.palestineremembered.com/Acre/Arab-al-Samniyya/index.html Welcome To 'Arab al-Samniyya] *[http://www.alnakba.org/villages/acre/arab.htm Arab Al-Samniyya] at [[Khalil Sakakini Cultural Center]] {{Palestinian Arab villages depopulated during the 1948 Palestine War}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arab Al-Samniyya}} [[Category:District of Acre]] [[Category:Arab villages depopulated during the 1948 Arab–Israeli War]]
